messageBody:
(I don't like to top-post, but as these mails arrived in html-format, it
is much easier to do so...)

The example given, although an example of white box testing, doesn't
require to use anything private. It just requires you to take a look at
the implementation to find out what the interesting test conditions look
like.

Why shouldn't you use JUnit in this case?


-----Original Message-----
From: Berin Loritsch [mailto:bloritsch@...]
Sent: Dienstag, 7. Mai 2002 15:13
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Re: black box or white box?


> From: ipreussde [mailto:ilja.preuss@...]
>
> > > For example, for some index class, if you know it uses a linear
> list up
> > > to 5 items and then a hash table, choosing to test with 4 items
> to test
> > > the list case and also test with 5 items to test the hash table
> case is
> > > white box testing.
> >
> > Yes. That is an example of whitebox testing.
> >
> > [...]
> >
> > Different tools for different fools:
> >
> > JUnit is designed for blackbox testing. That is how it should be
> used.
> > The new JDK 1.4 assertion facilities are for whitebox testing.
> That is
> > how they should be used.
>
> Can you please explain why it would be a bad idea to use JUnit in the
> above example and how assertions would be the more appropriate tool?

For example, JUnit cannot test private methods and private attributes.
There is a lot that JUnit cannot do to test pre-conditions,
post-conditions,
and constants in an implementation. That is where the assert keyword
comes in. You test all the pre-conditions and constant conditions at
the
beginning, and the post-conditions and constant conditions at the end.

Because the assert command lives inside your class, it can have access
to everything your class has access to.

JUnit can test all the public methods, and should be used for that.
